stories.headline: 'IT CAN'T GET MUCH WORSE'
stories.summary: Residents in southwestern Pennsylvania continue to struggle a week after a deadly storm left many without power and food supplies, with frustration growing as they try to cope without electricity and rely on battery-powered devices and food pantries.

stories.headline: Situation has created some dark days for restaurants
stories.summary: Following a damaging windstorm that impacted approximately 400,000 people in the Pittsburgh region, many restaurants, including Green Tree, Regent Square, and others, face hardships due to ongoing power outages affecting business operations.

stories.headline: Duquesne aims to go big with new building
stories.summary: Duquesne University plans a 10-year master plan focusing on developing a new 80,000-square-foot health sciences facility featuring labs, classrooms, research spaces and hospital-like environments. The project aims to strengthen the university's health sciences reputation and is expected to consolidate programs currently at other locations into the new building.

stories.headline: TRUMP, CARNEY FACE OFF ON TRADE
stories.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney clashed over ongoing trade disputes at the White House. Both leaders emphasized their positions strongly, with Trump asserting tariffs and Canada responding firmly, indicating significant differences remain on trade policies.

stories.headline: Fetterman bashes article that questioned his health
stories.summary: U.S. Senator John Fetterman strongly denounced a critical article about his health and behavior as a 'hit piece.' He defended himself against concerns raised in the New York Magazine piece and addressed broader criticisms related to his political positions and personal health issues.

stories.headline: Miami-Dade County Commission picks a new member from West Miami
stories.summary: Natalie Milian Orbis, former West Miami Vice Mayor, has been appointed to fill the District 6 commissioner seat on the Miami-Dade County Commission. She succeeds Kevin Cabrera, who stepped down to become President Donald Trump’s ambassador to Panama. Orbis has experience as a commissioner and has been involved in Miami-Dade County government for many years. Her appointment was supported by the majority of commissioners, despite some opposition.

stories.headline: Miami-Dade Commission defies mayor, votes again to end adding fluoride to water
stories.summary: The Miami-Dade County Commission voted 8-4 to override Mayor Daniella Levine Cava’s veto and end the practice of adding fluoride to the county's water supply. This decision reflects ongoing local debates about public health policies regarding water fluoridation. The commission's decision stands despite the mayor's opposition.

stories.headline: Influential Orthodox rabbi, who reshaped Jewish Miami and helped heal, has died
stories.summary: Rabbi Sholom Dovber Lipskar, a transformative leader who made significant contributions to the Jewish community in Miami and beyond, has passed away at the age of 78. He dedicated much of his life to humanitarian work and led the Shul of Bal Harbour, helping Jewish communities thrive. His efforts were particularly noted after the tragic Surfside condo collapse, when his leadership provided support to families and responders.

stories.headline: U.S. intelligence report challenges Trump claim that Maduro controls Tren de Aragua
stories.summary: A report from the U.S. National Intelligence Council concludes that while the Venezuelan gang Tren de Aragua is feared, it is unlikely that the Venezuelan strongman Maduro regime directly controls it. This contradicts President Donald Trump's assertion that the regime uses the gang for its own purposes. The report highlights the complexity of Venezuelan law enforcement and political dynamics, stating that the regime views the gang both as a threat and as a group with which it has a limited relationship.

stories.headline: Maine housing advocates warn of 'tsunami' of USDA foreclosures
stories.summary: Federal officials say they are clearing over 800 delinquencies on rural homes left by the Biden administration, potentially hitting many Mainers hard. The USDA's Rural Development office has been slow to respond to questions about whether these foreclosures might escalate as loans remain unpaid. Advocates argue this crisis has been years in the making, with the agency currently tracking 400 foreclosures and 800 delinquent payments. So far, only a small fraction have appeared in court, but housing advocates warn a wave of foreclosures could hit Maine soon.

stories.headline: Supreme Court OKs trans troops ban
stories.summary: The Supreme Court has approved a policy banning transgender individuals from serving in the military, supporting moves by the White House to remove those service members. The decision is part of ongoing debates over military policies and rights of transgender people.

stories.headline: NEA cuts hit local arts groups
stories.summary: Funding reductions from the National Endowment for the Arts are impacting local arts organizations in Los Angeles, forcing many groups to seek alternative grants to sustain their operations.

stories.headline: Californians ding Newsom in poll
stories.summary: A recent state poll shows that voters are more critical than supportive of Governor Gavin Newsom, reflecting ongoing challenges and public sentiment in California's political landscape.

stories.headline: Energy Star may go dark in new shake-up
stories.summary: The Environmental Protection Agency plans to reorganize divisions that run the Energy Star program, which rates appliances for energy efficiency. The proposed changes may reduce the program's scope and risk limiting its effectiveness in helping consumers reduce energy costs amid climate change concerns. The shake-up aligns with administrative adjustments under the Trump administration.

stories.headline: Bay Area sees older moms
stories.summary: The Bay Area leads the nation in delaying motherhood as women pursue careers and other life goals. Counties have high proportions of women giving birth in their 40s, reflecting broader shifts in social norms, economic opportunity, and access to reproductive technology. Marin County has the highest share of births to women aged 40 and over in the U.S.

stories.headline: What to expect as Real ID deadline arrives
stories.summary: The federal government's Real ID program rollout has been delayed twice, but travelers should prepare for upcoming changes at airports nationwide. Officials emphasize the need for a Real ID or acceptable form of identification for travel at TSA checkpoints. Many travelers still without compliant IDs may face delays and questioning at airport security.

stories.headline: Reopen Alcatraz? Tourists look around and ask: 'Why?'
stories.summary: Following President Trump's call to repurpose Alcatraz prison as a facility to detain criminals, visitors and experts voice confusion. Many tourists and managers are unsure how the historic site, long shuttered and preserved as a national park and tourist spot, could function anew in that role.

stories.headline: L.A. County declares hepatitis A outbreak
stories.summary: Los Angeles County has declared a communitywide hepatitis A outbreak, with a significant rise in cases and a 13-month-old death linked to the virus. Health officials warn of the highest cases in a decade and emphasize timely public health interventions to curb infections, especially among vulnerable populations.

stories.headline: Carney insists Canada ‘not for sale’
stories.summary: President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney held a meeting at the White House revealing no signs of easing trade tensions. Carney emphasized Canada is not for sale despite Trump's calls for Canada to become the 51st state. The discussion highlighted a range of issues from tariffs to US-Canada relations with Trump expecting time for talks.

stories.headline: REAL ID rush
stories.summary: A line formed outside the Secretary of State's office in Chicago as residents sought to obtain a state ID at the REAL ID Supercenter. The deadline for REAL ID requirements is approaching, prompting many to apply. Officials are providing information to ensure people meet the necessary identification standards.

stories.headline: Did British woman use ICE to avoid facing trial?
stories.summary: Kimberly Hall, a British citizen, was arrested with 21 bundles of cocaine at O’Hare International Airport and faces felony drug charges. Prosecutors claim she sought to evade trial by attempting to get deported through federal immigration channels. Hall’s attorney contested the claims, arguing that the detention by Immigration and Customs Enforcement was improper and linked to the unpredictability of the current administration.

stories.headline: Race to succeed Durbin gets more crowded
stories.summary: The Democratic race to replace retiring U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin intensifies as Rep. Robin Kelly enters the contest, setting up a potential proxy battle with Governor J.B. Pritzker. Meanwhile, another candidate, Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi, positions himself as a 'radical common sense progressive,' promising tough stances on issues like the economy and immigration, complicating the primary field further.

stories.headline: A CONCLAVE LIKE NO OTHER
stories.summary: Pope Francis' outreach to the church's peripheries is impacting the selection of his successor in the upcoming conclave starting May 7. While many traditions remain, new developments reflecting Francis' influence are shaping the proceedings. Of the 252 cardinals, 135 are younger than 80 and eligible to vote, with 108 appointed by Pope Francis himself, presenting a potential shift in the church's future leadership.

stories.headline: Ranking the 14 QBs Dolphins will face
stories.summary: A sports feature ranks the 14 quarterbacks the Dolphins will face in the upcoming season, providing fans an insight into key players and challenges ahead for the team.

stories.headline: Lawsuit challenges new amendment process
stories.summary: A group supporting a 2026 proposed constitutional amendment to expand Medicaid is challenging Florida's new restrictions on the public's ability to amend the state constitution. Florida Decides HealthCare filed the lawsuit, arguing the restrictions violate First Amendment rights. The group is working to collect signatures to qualify for the 2026 ballot but now faces increased hurdles due to new regulations, which they argue are repressive and undermine true citizen power.

stories.headline: Applications pour in for job to run PB County
stories.summary: More than 200 applicants from across the United States are vying to become Palm Beach County's next administrator, with a salary up to $477,000 annually. Notable applicants include several deputy and assistant county administrators, former chief executive officer of Park Harbor-Hickam military base, and local government superintendents and administrators. The selection process is underway with a wide pool of qualified candidates.

stories.headline: Man says weapons, badges for games
stories.summary: Authorities in West Palm Beach report that Damien Allen, 22, accused of impersonating deputies and stockpiling weapons, is involved in role-playing games rather than criminal activity. Weapons, tactical gear, and fake law enforcement uniforms were found at Allen's home and are said to be used for live-action role playing (LARP), not for committing crimes. The defense highlighted the gaming and role-playing nature of the evidence.

stories.headline: Curtain drops on arts funding
stories.summary: The Varsity Cinema in Des Moines and FilmScene in Iowa City, among other arts organizations, lost grants following cuts to the National Endowment for the Arts by the Trump administration. Additionally, the Des Moines Metro Opera, an NEA funding recipient for 40 years, was notified it will not receive a $25,000 grant for 2025, impacting numerous organizations nationwide.

stories.headline: Reynolds' energy bill is getting resistance
stories.summary: Gov. Kim Reynolds faces growing opposition to her broad energy bill, with a coalition of business, manufacturing, tech, and consumer groups arguing it could cost Iowans tens of millions of dollars more annually than necessary to meet state power demands. Former Iowa utility regulators also sent a letter expressing concern about companion bills that may lead to higher consumer energy bills, estimating nearly $300 million more in costs annually.

stories.headline: Immigrant rights nonprofit fights Iowa House panel’s demand
stories.summary: An Iowa immigrant rights nonprofit is pushing back against a letter from the state House Government Oversight Committee demanding sensitive information about the group's work. The letter, sent by committee chair Rep. Charley Thomson, directs the Iowa Migrant Movement for Justice to turn over tax documents and donor information, escalating tensions between immigrant advocacy groups and lawmakers.

stories.headline: Parents sue district after allegations against staff member
stories.summary: Parents of Valley View Elementary School students filed a $50 million tort claim against Boise School District after a special education para-professional was accused of producing pornography of a child. The accused employee, Gavin Snow, committed suicide after police attempted an arrest on suspicion of child sexual abuse and exploitation crimes. The school district is facing allegations and investigations related to the situation.

stories.headline: Idaho man sues Meridian police, alleging excessive force
stories.summary: James Seward filed a lawsuit against the Meridian Police Department claiming excessive force after Officer Donald Heida allegedly punched him multiple times during an arrest, causing serious injuries. The incident was captured on body-camera footage showing the officer hitting Seward repeatedly, which led to a police investigation and public scrutiny. Seward's lawsuit seeks at least $75,000 in damages for physical, mental, and emotional injuries caused by the officers' actions.

stories.headline: What the outgoing mayor foresees for Garden City
stories.summary: John Evans, the outgoing mayor of Garden City, reflects on the city's growth and development during his tenure. Since taking office in 2006, the city has seen significant development, including attracting artists, businesses, and residents despite higher costs across the Boise river. Evans announced he will not run in the upcoming mayoral race after serving multiple terms and years on the City Council.

stories.headline: Accomplished Boise woman celebrates 108th birthday
stories.summary: Margaret Mortenson, a Boise resident and one of the first female pharmacists in Idaho, celebrated her 108th birthday. She taught hundreds of soldiers to be ground crew during World War II and was recognized by U.S. Rep. Mike Simpson in Congress. Mortenson shared how she overcame obstacles in her career and life, emphasizing the importance of leaving happy memories for her children and grandchildren.

stories.headline: Texas could recoup up to $800M
stories.summary: Congress is considering nearly $800 million in reimbursements that could go to Texas for border security measures during the Biden administration. This funding is part of a larger spending bill which also includes tax cuts put forth by President Donald Trump. The reimbursements would support immigration enforcement activities along the southern border, especially as Texas has been actively funding border operations under Governor Abbott's 'Operation Lone Star.'

stories.headline: House passes rezoning measure
stories.summary: The Texas House passed a bill limiting the power to block rezoning, aimed at curbing local homeowners' ability to use a law known as the 'tyrant's veto' to prevent development proposals. The measure, which passed in bipartisan fashion, would increase the percentage of protestors required to officially block rezoning changes, making it harder to override zoning ordinances. The bill was supported by Republican state representatives and opposed by some Democrats who saw it as limiting neighborhood influence on zoning.

stories.headline: A wet Tuesday morning in Austin
stories.summary: Heavy rain and flooding impacted Austin on Tuesday, causing hazardous conditions including road closures and flooding in areas like Bull Creek and Spicewood Springs Road. Pedestrians used umbrellas to cross bridges amid ongoing scattered thunderstorm activity anticipated to continue through May 8.

stories.headline: Canada PM tries charm after tough talk on Trump
stories.summary: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney visited Washington and worked to repair relations following tense remarks from President Donald Trump who expressed opposition to Canada joining the 51st state. Carney aimed to charm Trump and emphasize shared values and cooperation despite recent stresses in diplomatic relations between the two nations.

stories.headline: Hundreds of killers may face resentencing
stories.summary: Hundreds of convicted killers in Flint could be eligible for resentencing following a Michigan Supreme Court ruling that mandates first-degree murder sentences for 19 and 20-year-olds without parole are unconstitutional. Prosecutors fear a caseload overflow as about 400 defendants in Wayne County alone could seek resentencing. Critics, including relatives of murder victims, oppose this ruling, citing concerns about public safety and justice for victims.

stories.headline: Smokey Robinson accused of sex assault by ex-housekeepers
stories.summary: Four former housekeepers of Smokey Robinson have alleged in a lawsuit that the Motown music luminary repeatedly sexually assaulted and raped them while they worked for him. The suit seeks at least $50 million in damages over alleged assaults and labor violations occurring between 2007 and 2024 in a hostile work environment.

stories.headline: Suit seeks $500M over recorded strip searches at women's prison
stories.summary: Women inside a Michigan prison allege they were subjected to trauma and illegal videotaping during strip searches using hidden cameras. The lawsuit was filed against the Women's Huron Valley Correctional Facility and its staff, seeking $500 million in damages for violations and psychological harm caused by these practices.

stories.headline: DPD honors fallen officers
stories.summary: Dallas Police Department held its annual service to honor officers who gave their lives during duty. The ceremony, moved indoors due to rain, included placing a yellow rose on the Dallas Police Memorial and was attended by police chief, command staff, dignitaries, and families of the deceased officers. Emotional moments included a hug shared between patrol officer and the mother of fallen officer Darron Lee Burks.

stories.headline: Supreme Court allows trans ban
stories.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court upheld President Trump's order disqualifying transgender people from military service amid ongoing legal challenges. The Court allowed the administration to enforce the ban while related lawsuits proceed, which disqualifies transgender military service members from serving openly. The decision has sparked responses from officials, including Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, who supported the policy as consistent with military readiness.

stories.headline: Fears driving missed classes
stories.summary: Data shows that violence and gun threats have led many students, especially in Cleburne ISD, to miss classes due to fear, causing disruption in young children's learning and interrupted focus in classrooms. Safety-related waivers for low attendance have increased, and school officials along with The Dallas Morning News have examined attendance waivers related to safety threats in various North Texas school districts, underscoring how disruptive threats against schools have become.

stories.headline: State to tackle dementia
stories.summary: Texas plans to fund research and authorize billions of dollars for Dementia Prevention and Research Institute. The initiative aims to address devastating brain diseases affecting nearly 7 million Americans, including over half a million Texans. Legislation that would create this landmark research project has moved from the House to the Senate and is nearing final approval amid hopes it could pave the way for stronger Alzheimer's and dementia treatments.

stories.headline: Is number up for the Texas Lottery?
stories.summary: Some legislators are pushing to eliminate the Texas Lottery amid questions about its management and multiple criminal investigations. Concerns arose after lottery officials violated Texas law by allowing couriers to take online ticket orders, which has led to investigations by the Texas Rangers and Attorney General Ken Paxton into potential crimes related to multimillion-dollar jackpots.

stories.headline: Kids' 1st boat ride turned to disaster
stories.summary: A first boat ride for children ended tragically when a powerboat slammed into the back of a ferry near Clearwater, killing a Palm Harbor man and injuring ten others, including an eight-month pregnant woman. Passengers accuse the boater of not taking responsibility for the crash. Authorities continue investigating this incident that occurred during a trip to a beach festival.

stories.headline: Ono says he's 'in alignment' with Florida's vision for UF
stories.summary: Santa Ono, the sole finalist for the University of Florida's presidency, participated in sessions with students and faculty highlighting his vision for the future of liberal arts and state funding. Ono expressed he is aligned with Florida's goals and is expected to officially assume the role after approval from the Florida Board of Governors.

stories.headline: Experts in every office?
stories.summary: More than a dozen sheriff's offices in Florida report having no trained personnel to direct people to aid through the Hope Florida liaison program announced by Gov. Ron DeSantis and first lady Casey DeSantis. Despite the initiative aiming to have experts in every sheriff's office to connect people in need with community resources, some agencies have little interaction with the program and question its effectiveness.

stories.headline: Light rail: Will new Redmond stations fill train cars?
stories.summary: Each Eastside light rail train can carry only a couple of dozen riders. After several months of moderate ridership, forecasts predict daily boardings could peak in the thousands by mid-2024 when extensions to Marymoor Village and Downtown Redmond open. The light rail stations at Microsoft headquarters and downtown Bellevue are seen as key factors that might boost ridership significantly. The agency estimates about 5,900 passenger boardings a day will occur at these stations, providing hope for transit expansion success.

stories.headline: India fires into Pakistani territory
stories.summary: India fired missiles into Pakistani-controlled territory in several locations early Wednesday, killing at least 19 people including a child, in what Pakistan's leader called an act of war. The attack came after last month's attack in India-controlled Kashmir and has escalated tensions as Pakistan claims to have shot down Indian fighter jets in retaliation. Indian police and medical services are responding to the attacks, and both countries have condemned each other's actions.

stories.headline: Justices rule Trump can enforce ban on transgender military members
stories.summary: The Supreme Court decided that the Trump administration may reinstate its ban on transgender people serving in the military, blocking an order from a Tacoma federal judge that paused the move. The emergency ruling, which was unsigned and did not include a reason for allowing the ban to move forward, takes immediate effect and will remain in place while legal challenges focused on its constitutionality proceed. The court's three liberal members noted they would have rejected the Trump administration's request.

stories.headline: UW protest ends with 31 arrests at occupied campus building
stories.summary: Thirty-one protesters were arrested after occupying a new engineering building at the University of Washington to cut ties with Boeing and end what they called a targeted assault on pro-Palestine activism. Protesters blocked entrances and windows, repurposing the building as a 'dangerous, violent and illegal' encampment drawing attention to manufacturing machines valued at $35,000. Officers, including riot gear, responded to the unauthorized occupation and ended the protest citing trespassing and disorderly conduct.

stories.headline: Canada’s new leader tries charm after tough talk on Trump
stories.summary: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney used a mixture of flattery and firmness in his first meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump, trying to soften tensions after a principled resistance to Washington following the 2024 U.S. election. The Oval Office encounter offered a respectful repartee despite underlying concerns by Canadian leaders about potential trade and tariff disputes that could harm neighbor relations. Carney aims to manage tariffs and the broader relationship with the U.S. amid a significant crisis.

stories.headline: 3rd measles case confirmed in Mo.
stories.summary: A third measles case was confirmed in Missouri, specifically a man in southeastern New Madrid County who visited the Busy St. Louis Aquarium. Health officials from Missouri and Illinois are investigating due to the person's exposure in an area restaurant and aquarium. Efforts to notify potential exposures, especially to children, are underway as officials emphasize strict cleaning protocols to prevent further spread of the virus.

stories.headline: Arts groups rocked by cuts
stories.summary: Local arts organizations in St. Louis face significant funding cuts following recommendations by the National Endowment for the Arts and a reduced 2026 federal budget proposal for arts funding. Grants ranging from $10,000 to $45,000 promised to 14 area organizations are cut or reduced, impacting groups such as the St. Louis Shakespeare Festival, Cinema St. Louis, and the St. Louis Black Repertory Company among others. The cuts have caused concern across the local arts community about reduced capacity and future sustainability.

stories.headline: St. Louis settles lawsuit for $4M
stories.summary: St. Louis city officials agreed to a $4 million settlement for a lawsuit alleging 'hellish and inhumane conditions' at the now-closed Medium Security Institution. The settlement ends a seven-year legal battle and provides compensation to roughly 16,000 former detainees based on stay length. The facility was closed in 2022 due to poor conditions and is being demolished. The settlement is seen as a significant outcome for justice reform advocates.

stories.headline: Boy was a 'football star'
stories.summary: A young boy from a St. Louis County neighborhood was shot and killed. His father was charged with felony child endangerment related to the shooting. The boy was known as a football star and was involved in sports with the Mathews-Dickey Boys & Girls Club and the United Youth Sports All-American Bowl. Authorities continue to investigate the case involving a loaded gun found at the house.

stories.headline: CLINIC OFFERS FREE CARE
stories.summary: A free health clinic was held at America's Center in downtown St. Louis by Pathway to Health, a humanitarian mission sponsored by the Seventh-day Adventist Church. The clinic provided free medical care on a first-come, first-served basis for several days.

stories.headline: Carney tells Trump that Canada is not for sale
stories.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney faced off in the Oval Office amid ongoing trade tensions. Carney firmly rejected Trump's calls to make Canada the 51st state, asserting the nation was 'not for sale.' Their meeting, while civil, revealed deeper disagreements over tariffs and trade policies between the two countries.

stories.headline: Ice has all but disappeared from St. Paul Island. It changed everything.
stories.summary: Bering Sea warming has led to the disappearance of ice around St. Paul Island, Alaska, adversely affecting fish, crab, and bird populations and altering the community's way of life. The island experienced a record run of above-freezing temperatures, significantly impacting the environment and local subsistence practices.

stories.headline: DHS chief Noem says travelers with no REAL ID can fly for now
stories.summary: The Department of Homeland Security has assured travelers without a REAL ID they can still fly temporarily while states update their IDs before the May 7 deadline. TSA warned of possible delays for those lacking proper identification, but security checkpoints will accept other forms of ID until then. DHS head Kristi Noem emphasized ongoing efforts to ensure compliance with federal ID requirements.

stories.headline: Justices let Trump ban transgender troops while case continues
stories.summary: The Supreme Court allowed President Trump's policy banning transgender troops from the military to remain in effect while legal challenges continue. The court granted a lower court ruling blocking Trump's executive order nationwide pending further proceedings, amid debate over the policy's impact on LGBTQ+ military members.

stories.headline: 'In sickness and in health' tested more when wife is ill
stories.summary: Jennifer Whitlock married her husband Ronnie in rural Texas in 2021, weeks after he was diagnosed with stage 4 blood cancer. The couple faced challenges as Jennifer balanced full-time work while caring for Ronnie, whose illness eventually led to his death in March 2022. The experience tested their relationship, highlighting difficulties couples endure when one partner falls seriously ill, including emotional and household struggles.

stories.headline: Carney: Canada is 'not for sale'
stories.summary: During high-stakes meetings on May 6 about foreign affairs and domestic spending, President Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney addressed recent reports about the state of the North American economy. Carney emphasized that Canada is not for sale despite pressures and economic contraction. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem also participated in discussions, highlighting coordination between the two North American leaders.

stories.headline: Africa plays a big role in Catholicism's future
stories.summary: The Catholic Church sees Africa as a vital part of its future, with Pope Francis focusing on the continent's young population and expanding Christian outreach. Africa hosts a growing number of Catholics, which contrasts with declining numbers elsewhere. African cardinals, such as Cardinal Desire Tsarahazana of Madagascar, are considered frontrunners in the upcoming papal conclave, reflecting the continent's influence on the Church's direction.

stories.headline: Justices uphold military trans ban
stories.summary: The Supreme Court will allow President Donald Trump's ban on transgender individuals serving in the military to take effect, but court challenges will continue. The decision, supported by the court's majority, rejects requests for explanations, while lawyers for transgender service members called the ruling "devastating." The White House views the decision as a victory despite ongoing legal battles.

stories.headline: A Conclave Like No Other
stories.summary: The conclave beginning May 7 to pick a successor to Pope Francis features many long-established rituals within a church nearly 2,000 years old. Cardinal electors are sequestered from the outside world until a new pope is chosen, with every person involved required to keep the proceedings secret. Within these traditions, some new developments have emerged, but none majorly impact the process. Pope Francis' outreach to 'peripheries' impacts cardinals choosing the successor, but it likely eliminates a hardcore conservative.

stories.headline: Popular deli back in town
stories.summary: Little Pickle, a modern New York-style deli, has reopened in Phoenix. Readers are given an exclusive first look at the brick-and-mortar location, marking a return for the popular dining spot.

stories.headline: Makes good on investment
stories.summary: Grand Canyon University’s softball team took a chance on Canyon View’s Savannah Kirk, who now leads them into the WAC tournament, evidencing a good investment by the team and the school.

stories.headline: Emily Pike's family, DC officials meet
stories.summary: FBI Director Kash Patel promised Emily Pike’s family updates on the case of the 14-year-old whose dismembered body was found north of Globe on Valentine's Day. Family members, including Emily’s uncle and sister, have also been in contact with officials. The case continues to draw attention, correlating with Missing and Murdered Indigenous Persons Awareness Day.

stories.headline: Lost, pregnant, alone: Migrant tells her story
stories.summary: Erika Mateo, a Guatemalan migrant, was found wandering the Arizona desert while pregnant and near the end of her pregnancy. Separated from her group for being unable to keep up, she shared how she faced fear and loneliness, fearing she might lose her unborn child. Border agents found her and she recounted her ordeal, including the fear of being caught and the exhaustion she felt.

stories.headline: UK president defends canceled minority graduations
stories.summary: University of Kentucky President Eli Capilouto defended the cancellation of graduation celebrations for minority students, stating it was required to comply with law and federal diversity policies. He emphasized that the decision was in response to tough federal and state regulations and investigations into diversity, equity, and inclusion practices at universities, including UK. Capilouto asserted that cancelling such celebrations is necessary to protect the community and comply with legal mandates.

stories.headline: Cuts could be 'devastating' for Kentucky public media
stories.summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order directing the halt of federal funding to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, potentially crippling Kentucky Education Television and 14 public radio stations. PBS and NPR officials plan to challenge the order, which threatens key public broadcasting resources. PBS head Paula Kerger and NPR's Katherine Maher expressed grave concerns, highlighting the impact on educational programming and public service in Kentucky.

stories.headline: Father charged in deadly arson asks to attend funerals
stories.summary: A Frankfort father charged with arson resulting in the deaths of his two teenage sons requested permission to attend their funerals. Dustin Fields, 44, allegedly started a fire at his home on April 30, 2025, which destroyed the residence and killed the boys. No decision has yet been made regarding his attendance at the funerals. Fields was charged with first-degree arson after a district court arraignment.

stories.headline: Michigan unhappy with Trump
stories.summary: A poll by EPIC-MRA in Lansing reveals most Michigan voters give President Donald Trump poor marks for his first 100 days in office, with 56% negative ratings. Concerns include economic policy, inflation, immigration, and handling of international conflicts. The poll indicates trouble for Trump and Republican midterm candidates in Michigan.

stories.headline: They worry about policies: 'Every person has value'
stories.summary: Liam Canty, a 13-year-old autistic boy, and other Michigan autistic teens speak out against incorrect vaccine statements made by RFK Jr. They stress the importance of recognizing every person's value despite disabilities and criticize misleading comments about autism and vaccines.

stories.headline: Canadian PM to Trump: We're not for sale
stories.summary: During a White House meeting, Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney assured President Donald Trump that Canada is firm and not for sale despite Trump’s aggressive trade rhetoric. Carney emphasized a focus on the economy and dismissed notion that Canada could be sacrificed in political deals as Trump’s political fortunes shift.

stories.headline: Trump budget cuts into state funds
stories.summary: Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson warns that reductions in federal funds proposed by President Donald Trump could result in a $430 million loss for the state. Despite this, a special legislative session is considered unlikely. The impact of these cuts could severely challenge the Maryland General Assembly’s budgeting efforts, especially amid uncertain federal funding and the upcoming legislative session in January.

stories.headline: Officials to vote on Pimlico demolition
stories.summary: The Maryland Board of Public Works is expected to approve the demolition contract for the Pimlico racetrack, a year ahead of the Preakness Stakes. This follows extensive planning and deliberations, with demolition targeted for late June or July and a new site aimed at driving economic activity to the area. The measure includes a $14.3 million demolition and construction budget, with an approved $800,000 pre-construction contract.

stories.headline: Some criticize Ravens' wording of decision to release kicker Tucker
stories.summary: The Baltimore Ravens released kicker Justin Tucker, a highly notable player on the team, with very limited details provided regarding the decision. The article highlights the significant impact Tucker made during his career and the reaction of fans, including his family. Additionally, there is discussion surrounding the tone of team management's statements and his contributions on and off the field.

stories.headline: Moore signs bill to alter Blueprint
stories.summary: Governor Wes Moore signed legislation that restructures Maryland's land-mark Blueprint for the Future education reform policy. The bill maintains community school funding but pauses teacher collaborative time. The legislation reflects compromise amid debates within the Maryland General Assembly and the governor's office. Republicans expressed concerns about the bill's provisions and structural budget effects.

stories.headline: Trump, Carney meet, show vast differences
stories.summary: In a meeting in Washington, U.S. President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney displayed significant disagreement on tariffs and statehood issues. Carney described conversations with Trump as wide-ranging but aggressive on tariffs, while Trump remained critical of Carney's stance. The article also touches on recent US Supreme Court decisions, transgender military policies, and Capitol Hill legislative disputes involving homeland security and immigration.

stories.headline: U.S. admiral warns of ‘rapid boil’ toward Chinese invasion of Taiwan
stories.summary: Admiral Samuel J. Paparo, commander of the U.S. Indo-Pacific Command, warned that Chinese forces are escalating preparations for a potential invasion of Taiwan, describing the situation as a 'rapid boil.' The comments come amid increased Chinese military drills and amphibious fleet movements near Taiwan. The U.S. military is closely monitoring these developments amid heightened tensions in the region.

stories.headline: Trump halts U.S. strikes, says Houthis 'capitulated'
stories.summary: President Trump announced that the U.S. will stop airstrikes on the Houthis in Yemen, stating that the terrorists have reached out to surrender. He emphasized that the Houthis no longer want to fight and accepted a ceasefire, while Israeli forces continue their operations against Yemeni terrorists. Trump committed to taking their word seriously and ceasing bombings immediately.

stories.headline: African voices wary as conservatives rally around Cardinal Sarah for pope
stories.summary: Cardinal Robert Sarah, a conservative Catholic from Guinea, has emerged as a frontrunner in the papal conclave with support from some African theologians and conservative Catholics worldwide. However, African Catholic thinkers express concern over his conservative stance, particularly on issues like mass migration, as debates intensify ahead of the vote for the next pope in the Sistine Chapel.

stories.headline: FBI flubbed 2017 inquiry of gunman on ball field
stories.summary: A House Republican report revealed that the FBI's 2017 inquiry into a left-wing gunman who shot Republican Steve Scalise at a baseball practice was biased and failed to consider political motives. The report challenged the FBI's initial findings and criticized the agency’s handling of the investigation, suggesting a ‘suicide by cop’ theory instead of a politically motivated attack. The incident prompted scrutiny of the FBI’s investigative methods at the time.

stories.headline: Justices revive ban on transgender troops pending lower court appeals
stories.summary: The Supreme Court upheld President Trump's ban on transgender individuals serving in the military, preventing courts from blocking the policy while appeals proceed. The ruling was hailed by the Department of Defense but criticized by LGBTQ groups and civil rights advocates, who view it as discriminatory. The court's decision marks a significant moment in the ongoing legal battles surrounding transgender military service.

stories.headline: Bills would increase license fees, require park passes
stories.summary: Michigan lawmakers have proposed bipartisan bills to raise fees for hunting and fishing licenses for the first time in over a decade to address funding shortages for wildlife conservation and state parks. The legislation aims to curb declining numbers of hunters and anglers and transition to an inflation-driven cost process covering expenses from fish food to fuel. Additional measures include requirements for annual recreational passports for vehicle access to parks and boating sites. The proposed changes reflect a state-wide effort to support natural resource management despite some public dissatisfaction with new costs.

stories.headline: Don’t have a REAL ID yet? That could cause you travel headaches.
stories.summary: The deadline for obtaining a REAL ID is approaching amid prior delays and confusion. This federally compliant ID is needed for domestic flights and access to certain federal buildings. Homeland Security officials say travelers without a REAL ID should prepare for additional steps at TSA checkpoints. The ID features new security standards and passes at airports nationwide. Travelers are advised to check their state's driver's licensing agency for requirements and visit a DMV to obtain one if needed. The article highlights the importance of having an enhanced ID for smooth travel nationwide and internationally within the U.S. territories.

stories.headline: Tariffs could add up to $15,000 to the cost of making a vehicle
stories.summary: A new report analyzes the impact of U.S. tariffs on vehicles including trucks, SUVs, and cars imported from Europe and Asia. The study categorizes cost burdens into high, medium, and lower impact ranges, with high impact vehicles like luxury SUVs possibly facing cost increases from $10,000 to $12,000. The tariffs affect battery-electric vehicles and many popular vehicle brands. This price increase is expected to add a considerable financial burden to automakers and consumers alike, with medium impact vehicles potentially incurring hundreds to thousands of dollars in extra costs.

stories.headline: Girl dies after being caught in flood
stories.summary: A 10-year-old girl from Brenham was found dead after being swept away by rising floodwaters caused by severe thunderstorms moving through several Houston area counties. Authorities conducted water-based rescue operations and used thermal imaging drones but were unsuccessful in locating her in time.

stories.headline: Whitmire presents $7 billion balanced budget
stories.summary: Mayor John Whitmire unveiled a $7 billion city budget proposal that includes no new fees, tax hikes, or deficit, aiming to balance the city's finances despite a $330 million deficit during his term. The budget includes investments in infrastructure and avoids withdrawing further Metro dollars, crediting department consolidations for eliminating the deficit.

stories.headline: State lawmakers reach agreement on property tax relief
stories.summary: Texas state lawmakers agreed on a new property tax relief deal involving nearly $3 billion in new relief, primarily benefiting homeowners with cuts to the homestead exemption and disability owners. The proposal, which awaits final sign-off, is designed to reduce taxes by adjusting exemptions and limiting appraisal increases, supported by Republican leadership and business interests.

stories.headline: Court appointment office's head draws backlash
stories.summary: Kenneth Hardin, director of Harris County's Managed Assigned Counsel, faces criticism after stepping down as chairman of a judicial advisory board. Criminal defense lawyer Mark Hochglauße resigned from the board, highlighting ongoing grievances and controversy surrounding the oversight of defense attorney appointment and reviews in the county.

stories.headline: 7 killed, 26 hurt in escalating attacks by Russia, Ukraine
stories.summary: At least seven people were killed and 26 injured in overnight attacks between Russia and Ukraine, with Ukrainian drone strikes targeting Moscow and other Russian cities, and Russia using bombs and artillery on Ukrainian regions. The attacks caused damage to infrastructure and civilian areas in Kharkiv and other parts of Ukraine. Ukrainian officials reported a sustained assault involving guided bombs and drones during the conflict escalating tensions with claims of over 100 drones launched by Ukraine over Russian regions.

stories.headline: Supreme Court lets Trump enforce transgender troop ban
stories.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that the Trump administration may enforce its ban on transgender troops serving in the military, a policy previously blocked by lower courts. The ruling was unsigned, without explanation, and will remain in place while legal challenges continue. The court's three liberal members dissented without reasons. The ban was initially introduced by President Trump but faced legal setbacks under the Biden administration. The ban has been criticized for conflicting with soldiers' identity and integrity.

stories.headline: Democrats offer amended sex solicitation bill
stories.summary: California Democratic lawmakers have introduced an amended bill that strengthens penalties for soliciting sex from minors aged 16 and 17. The amended legislation, Assembly Bill 379, seeks to make felony charges possible for adults soliciting sex or exchange of goods with minors, and aims to keep felony charges on the first offense if the offender is more than three years older than the victim. It also requires felony sex crimes convictions for sex offenders in California, with certain exceptions for those under age 18.

stories.headline: KCK schools rely on virtual teachers during shortage
stories.summary: Kansas City, Kansas public schools are struggling with a shortage of qualified teachers, leading them to contract with Proximity Learning, a company providing certified teachers for virtual instruction. This arrangement helps address the ongoing teacher shortage that affects campuses nationwide, but students like Moni Khadka express challenges with the split attention between virtual and in-person teachers and difficulties understanding some subjects remotely.

stories.headline: One of KC’s last hot dog vendors posts up outside weed shop
stories.summary: Jason Vanderlinden, a longstanding hot dog vendor in Kansas City, has set up his hot dog stand outside a marijuana dispensary at 6200 Troost Ave. Despite challenges such as minor infractions and the pandemic, Vanderlinden continues to operate, noting the unique combination of sausages and stoners. His location is popular among downtown workers and cannabis customers.

stories.headline: DOJ at odds with Kansas, Missouri over abortion pill suit
stories.summary: The Department of Justice, under President Donald Trump, is challenging a legal suit brought by Missouri and Kansas concerning abortion pill restrictions. The DOJ argues that the states' legal actions should be dismissed or transferred to a federal court and criticizes the states' approach to restricting the abortion medication mifepristone, emphasizing the political and legal tensions involved.

stories.headline: India strikes Pakistan
stories.summary: India conducted airstrikes targeting terror camps in Pakistan, which Indian officials say was retaliation for recent terror attacks. The strikes risk escalation of conflict and have broader implications for the ongoing tensions between the two countries.

stories.headline: City budget would boost spending on housing office
stories.summary: Santa Fe's city budget includes a $2.6 million increase aimed at tackling affordable development and homelessness. The spending boost will fund housing shortage reduction initiatives and expand a shelter pilot program. City leaders emphasize the investment as a necessary response to worsening housing and homelessness issues, with total spending reaching $8.6 million next fiscal year, including funds allocated for the Affordable Housing Trust Fund. The plan supports establishing more micro-communities and shelters to serve those in need more effectively.

stories.headline: Local immigrant advocates say self-deportation offer cruel, shows ‘deep disconnect’
stories.summary: Local immigrant rights advocates in New Mexico criticize the Trump administration's 'self-deportation' program that offers $1,000 to undocumented immigrants to voluntarily leave the country. Advocates argue the offer is misleading, lacks substance, and could ruin asylum proceedings already underway. The U.S. Department of Homeland Security announced financial and travel assistance plans, but advocates say it betrays immigrant communities and is part of a harsh deportation agenda. Acceptance of the offer could result in detention and removal, with many immigrant groups warning about the offer's dangers and disconnect from immigrant community realities.

stories.headline: New crew no walk in park
stories.summary: Santa Fe is considering adding more full-time park maintenance staff to its budget to address increasing complaints about poor maintenance in city parks. The Parks and Open Space Division faces challenges with limited staffing and high costs. Despite criticism about current park conditions, the 2026 fiscal year budget does not yet include funding for additional workers. Mayor Alan Webber has proposed nearly $1 million in startup costs for this purpose, aiming to improve maintenance services across 77 city parks, 30 open spaces, and 121 miles of trails.

stories.headline: Area arrests in major federal drug ring bust
stories.summary: Federal agents seized millions of dollars worth of guns, drugs, and money in a five-state multistate drug bust that included New Mexico among others. The bust involved more than 4 million fentanyl pills, 79 pounds of methamphetamine, 17 pounds of cocaine, and numerous firearms. The operation dismantled one of the largest and most dangerous drug trafficking organizations in the U.S., with indictments filed in New Mexico and arrests made in multiple states. Heriberto Salazar Amaya, an official involved, described the group as a significant threat with leaders insulated from detection and heavy drug involvement.

stories.headline: Brooklyn Center OKs safety commission
stories.summary: Brooklyn Center approved a new public safety commission aimed at advising on police and violence prevention policies. The commission was created amid debates about public safety and the repeal of a prior threat response role. The city council voted to establish the commission after months of discussion and community concerns about police killings and safety measures, although its scope is still being defined.

stories.headline: Fewer kindergartners getting their MMR shots
stories.summary: Minnesota has seen a decline in measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccination rates among kindergarteners, with rates falling short of the 95% herd immunity target. The state reported two measles cases in 2025 and nationwide outbreaks have continued. Factors include medical and nonmedical exemptions, contributing to increased risk of community disease transmission.

stories.headline: Canada meeting: Mild to frosty
stories.summary: In a meeting at the Oval Office, Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and President Donald Trump discussed bilateral relations. Despite Carney's win on an anti-Trump platform, both leaders kept the talks civil. Carney emphasized that Canada is "not for sale," while Trump declined to offer direct praise, maintaining a cautious diplomatic tone.

stories.headline: Ordered freed, student leaves jail in Albert Lea
stories.summary: A U.S. district judge ordered the release of Mohammed Hoque, a Minnesota State University student from Bangladesh, who had been detained since March by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Hoque was held due to visa issues and alleged social media posts. After a legal fight and support from civil liberties groups, he was finally freed and reunited with family, though legal debates continue regarding his detention conditions.

stories.headline: State hits 84.2% grad rate, a record
stories.summary: Minnesota's high school graduation rate hit a record 84.2% in 2024, marking an improvement across nearly all student groups. Achievement gaps between white students and students of color have narrowed significantly. Education Commissioner Willie Jett highlighted the milestone as a positive indication of student success, particularly for the class of 2024 which overcame pandemic-era challenges.

stories.headline: Court lets Trump ban trans troops
stories.summary: The Supreme Court ruled to uphold former President Donald Trump's administration policy banning transgender individuals from serving in the military. The decision allows the policy that disqualifies transgender people from military service to remain in effect, amidst debates about the ethics and personal impact of the ban. The ruling clarifies that the ban can continue despite challenges arguing it is discriminatory.

stories.headline: Canceled arts grants cut deep in Philly
stories.summary: Dozens of Philadelphia-area arts organizations lost National Endowment for the Arts grants for 2025 due to federal budget cuts prioritizing other projects, inciting urgent pleas to Congress. The NEA denied the cuts were budget-related but they clash with President Trump's 'new priorities' and sparked criticism from local cultural groups.

stories.headline: Cricket Club's history gets national spotlight
stories.summary: The PGA Tour event at the Philadelphia Cricket Club's Wissahickon Course, the oldest U.S. club, brings national attention. Founded in 1854, the club hosted the 1907 U.S. Open, won by Alex Campbell. The legendary clay-pneumatic golf ball, invented there, revolutionized the game and set the stage for modern golf.

stories.headline: Harassment, fraud probes collide at Fire Dept.
stories.summary: The Philadelphia Fire Department is under dual investigation for harassment complaints against a commander and alleged overtime abuses. A law firm is probing sexual harassment complaints while an internal investigator looks into six-figure overtime payouts, highlighting accountability and public safety agency concerns.

stories.headline: Supreme Court allows ban on transgender troops
stories.summary: The Supreme Court temporarily allowed the Trump administration's ban on transgender military service to remain in place while reviewing the case. The decision represents a setback for civil rights advocates as the court considers whether the ban violates constitutional rights. The Justice Department supports the military's policy change.

stories.headline: Justices Allow President's Ban on Trans Troops
stories.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that the Trump administration may start enforcing a ban on transgender troops serving in the military that had been blocked by lower courts. The ruling was brief, unsigned, and gave no reasons, emphasizing that typical emergency applications remain in place while challenges proceed. The court's three liberal members dissented. The case concerns an executive order issued on President Trump's second term, affecting service members who identify as transgender.

stories.headline: Indian Forces Strike Pakistan After Massacre
stories.summary: India announced early Wednesday it had conducted strikes on Pakistan following an attack by armed militants that killed more than a dozen civilians in Indian-administered Kashmir. The Indian government said its forces struck nine sites in Pakistan and on Pakistan's side of the disputed Kashmir region, marking an escalation after previous periods of rising tensions. Pakistani officials denied the strikes and stated no Pakistani military facilities were targeted.

stories.headline: Even the Richest Man in the World Cannot Escape His Neighbors
stories.summary: Despite his immense wealth, Elon Musk's neighbors have filed complaints against him over various disturbances such as late-night gate openings and loud noise. These disputes have escalated into legal and planning commission debates. Musk's lavish lifestyle has at times clashed with local community standards, highlighting that wealth does not exempt one from neighborhood conflicts.

stories.headline: After a Stumble, Merz Becomes German Leader
stories.summary: Friedrich Merz became Germany's 10th postwar chancellor after a historic stumble that could complicate efforts to address the nation's economy and military challenges. Merz initially fell six votes short in parliamentary elections but later narrowly won in a vote of confidence, becoming the German leader. His ascendance follows controversial government decisions and challenges within Germany's political coalition.

stories.headline: Canada Sends Trump a Signal: It’s Not for Sale
stories.summary: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada set a firm tone in his high-stakes meeting with President Trump, emphasizing that Canada is not going to become the 51st U.S. state and will avoid a public fight. He made it clear that some places are not for sale and would maintain Canadian sovereignty amid trade and political tensions. The relationship between the neighbors remains complex amid ongoing policy and trade discussions.

stories.headline: Squeeze of Tariffs Crosses Globe to a Dusty Used-Car Lot
stories.summary: Antonio Austin operates a used-car lot near Lawton, Oklahoma, and has been impacted by tariffs and global trade tensions. His inventory has been dropping amid difficulties importing auto parts mainly from China. The tariffs imposed by the Trump administration have increased his costs, affecting his ability to repair and sell cars profitably. This situation reflects broader economic consequences of trade policies on small businesses and used-car markets.

stories.headline: Knicks rally from 20 down, beat Celtics in OT in Game 1
stories.summary: In an exciting basketball game, the New York Knicks overcame a 20-point deficit to beat the Boston Celtics in overtime during Game 1. The thrilling rally highlighted the resilience and skill of the Knicks as they took an early series lead. This victory sets a competitive tone for the upcoming playoff games between these two rivals.

stories.headline: REAL ID raised privacy concerns from the start
stories.summary: The REAL ID enforcement deadline will take effect on May 7 after years of delays, requiring adults to have a compliant driver's license or ID to board domestic flights and enter federal facilities. However, privacy advocates and several states have raised concerns about the cost and privacy threats posed by the program. The Electronic Frontier Foundation says the program could marginalize undocumented people and that the unified standards might even make it easier to identify individuals at TSA checkpoints. The debate over REAL ID highlights ongoing tensions between security and privacy issues.

stories.headline: U.N.: U.S. could weaken climate reforms
stories.summary: An internal United Nations document shows the United States is seeking to weaken a global deal meant to help developing countries face climate change impacts. The Trump administration opposes reforms to the global financial system designed to aid developing countries, pushing against measures related to taxation, credit ratings, and fossil fuel subsidies. The administration is also said to want to remove mentions of climate, gender equality, and sustainability from the agreement. The 4th International Conference on Financing for Development is expected to involve over 140 countries and aims to set priorities for financing development goals.

stories.headline: 500K could lose health coverage
stories.summary: More than 500,000 New Yorkers could lose health insurance under proposed Medicaid work requirements being considered by Republicans in Congress, according to state officials. The proposal could lead up to 750,000 people losing health insurance. The work requirement is part of GOP efforts to reduce Medicaid costs by mandating that many adults get jobs or face losing coverage. Medicaid has become deeply entrenched in New York, and the proposal has sparked considerable opposition.

stories.headline: Top court lets Trump ban transgender troops
stories.summary: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that the Trump administration's ban on transgender troops serving openly in the military can be enforced while legal challenges proceed. The court's decision was brief and unsigned, citing the need to maintain military order during ongoing litigation about the policy's legality. The case revolves around President Biden's reversal of the ban and military policies on transgender service members.

stories.headline: Mohawk to up prices as $50M tariff bill expected
stories.summary: Mohawk Industries, a leading flooring manufacturer, plans to raise prices due to President Donald Trump's tariffs and plans for additional tariffs on imported products from China. The company expects the tariffs to cost about $50 million and is adjusting prices to compensate for increased import costs and supply challenges.

stories.headline: Squeezing the Central Office
stories.summary: Board members of Hamilton County Schools are pushing for more budget cuts to central office administration to prioritize school-based staff amid a $18.5 million budget shortfall. Proposals include eliminating 45 central office positions and removing a principal's choosing from every school to reduce expenses and preserve frontline services like substitute nurses and school buses.

stories.headline: New ID not yet needed to fly
stories.summary: Travelers who haven't obtained a REAL ID by the deadline were assured by Homeland Security that they can still fly after additional identity checks, though check-in may take longer. Officials warn that those without a compliant ID might face longer steps at security, but will be allowed to fly.

stories.headline: Council votes to hire Mack
stories.summary: Birmingham Police Capt. Torry Mack became Decatur's next police chief in an unconventional way Monday night after receiving unanimous support as chief on a night in which City Council President Jacob Ladner did not allow public comment except for certain ordinances and licenses. The council chamber was full and unusually quiet with many wearing black in protest over recent deaths of officers John Scott Jr. and Steve Perkins. The City Council seeks to fill the chief's position left vacant when Todd Pinion was pressured to step down in March following criticism of his handling of the fatal shooting of Perkins. Mack pleaded not guilty, and his trial is scheduled for June 9. Several people attending the meeting spoke about their struggles and mental health crises, including former police officer Scott who remains under investigation.

stories.headline: Budget would phase out rocket with ties to Huntsville
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's 2026 budget proposal calls for phasing out the Space Launch System (SLS), which is managed in Huntsville. The 2026 budget cuts $4 billion per launch and looks to reduce the number of flights from three to none after 2026. U.S. Senator Katie Britt expressed support for the SLS and NASA but noted that the final budget has yet to be released. The U.S. space program remains vital to national security and economic goals, and Alabama's congressional leaders continue to lobby for support to sustain manned lunar missions and advancements in space exploration.

stories.headline: Leaders face off over trade, '51st state'
stories.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney met in the Oval Office but showed no signs of resolving their ongoing trade war. Trump called for Canada to be the 51st state but Carney insisted Canada was 'not for sale' and shot back that 'time will tell.' Carney acknowledged that the meeting was civil but warned that rhetoric around tariffs could worsen discussions. The U.S. president stressed his position as just 'the way it is,' while the meeting highlighted the full spectrum of disagreements between the two leaders.

stories.headline: Cook Museum named North Ala. STEM Center
stories.summary: Gov. Kay Ivey designated the Cook Museum of Natural Science in Decatur as the North Alabama STEM Center with an appropriation of $9.5 million from the state for the museum's education budget toward expansion. The museum provides hands-on learning experiences for students from public, private, homeschool and schools from 21 Alabama counties with over 18,000 students annually on field trips and 7,000 participating in camps and classes. This funding is seen as a jumpstart to a long-term expansion effort.

stories.headline: Residents celebrate, mourn as Deep Thought nears end
stories.summary: More than a hundred people gathered at Milwaukee’s lakefront to witness the latest attempt to remove the iconic abandoned boat "Deep Thought" from the shoreline between Bradford Beach and McKinley Marina. Despite several removal attempts, the boat has been stuck since last October, leaving owners unable to operate it. The process has attracted community attention as residents both celebrate and mourn the impending end of the landmark's presence.

stories.headline: Author rejects honor after Waukesha book ban
stories.summary: Kate Giorgio, an author and alumnus of Waukesha North High School, declined the Wall of Stars honor after the school district removed her books from library shelves following a district ban. Giorgio, who has written numerous books and poetry collections, expressed that the award felt personal due to those who knew her well supporting it. She discovered her books were removed from the school district’s libraries without being widely checked out, prompting her rejection of the accolade.

stories.headline: Johnson: Medicaid should be in cuts
stories.summary: Wisconsin Senator Ron Johnson has warned that continuing with the current congressional Republicans’ budget framework without deeper federal spending reductions will fail to gain support. He highlights concerns that cutting programs like Medicaid is complicating the budget process and emphasizes the need for Republicans to slash federal spending to levels in line with those before the 2020 pandemic. Johnson's comments reflect ongoing disagreements among Republicans on Capitol Hill regarding specific spending cuts, including those related to Medicaid.

stories.headline: Kraft sees opening in Black areas
stories.summary: Kraft has chosen to base his campaign in Roxbury, a historically disenfranchised neighborhood, to connect with diverse communities and call for voter inclusion. This move highlights his deep community ties and experience as CEO of the Boys & Girls Club and campaign leader.

stories.headline: Developers point finger at housing rule
stories.summary: Developers blame strict housing regulations in Cambridge, particularly limits on affordable units which cut into profits, for limiting housing availability. The rules restrict new developments from including enough affordable options, contributing to higher housing costs despite significant demand in the area.

stories.headline: Victimized by DOGE, they dream of turning the tables
stories.summary: Terminated federal workers affected by Trump administration downsizing, including Maryland's Shernice Mundell, are exploring running for political office to influence change. Over 120,000 federal jobs were cut, motivating some former employees to pursue office to transform civil service and public policy.

stories.headline: Taking credit where it isn't due
stories.summary: President Trump highlighted private investment in chip manufacturing attributed to his administration, including $100 billion from TSMC to expand in Arizona. However, critics argue much of the investment was underway before Trump took office and that Biden's policies deserved more credit. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick supported the investments as a result of Trump’s leadership.

stories.headline: At Harvard, a scramble for funding
stories.summary: Harvard University faces disruption in its federally funded research programs due to potential loss of billions in federal grants linked to compliance with new White House demands. The freeze affects $2.2 billion in funding, raising concerns about research progress and student admissions. Education Secretary Linda McMahon highlighted issues of perceived racism in graduate schools as part of the controversy.

stories.headline: Volunteers among those hit by DOGE
stories.summary: Cuts directed by the Department of Government Efficiency, led by figures associated with Donald Trump and Elon Musk, have resulted in a $400 million reduction to AmeriCorps, jeopardizing volunteer programs that provide essential services such as food banking and relief distribution in California. This reduction disproportionately affects vulnerable populations and highlights challenges facing public service efforts. California's Governor Gavin Newsom has commented on the impacts of these cuts.

stories.headline: Arts groups vow to fight back after NEA grants cut
stories.summary: Bay Area arts organizations are responding to the National Endowment for the Arts rescinding crucial funding as part of the Trump administration's cultural overhaul. The funding cuts have significantly impacted local theaters, festivals, and nonprofits, jeopardizing their financial stability and forcing staff resignations. Affected organizations like the American Conservatory Theater and Berkeley Repertory Theatre are mobilizing to address the fallout and preserve their cultural contributions.

stories.headline: Alcatraz whim part of Trump’s strategy
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's announcement to reopen Alcatraz prison, despite its closure in the 1960s for being too expensive and inhumane, is seen by experts as a strategic move to drive the news cycle. The president's outlandish social media posts aim to focus national conversation on politically advantageous topics by goading media into debating controversial remarks. Political experts highlight how this tactic capitalizes on public support for tough crime policies and distracts from other issues.

stories.headline: Pier transformed to make art, not war
stories.summary: Descendants of shipyard workers are part of a massive redevelopment transforming Pier 70's historic Building 12 from an old shipbuilding facility into a site for housing, retail, and artistic creation. The project honors the legacy of those who built and engineered ships during World War II and now fosters new generations of makers designing sneakers, brewing beer, and crafting flowers. The redevelopment includes modern kilns and systems to support artisans and preserve the site's heritage.

stories.headline: Indiana man held over ICE error
stories.summary: A federal immigration judge was visibly irritated after learning a Honduran man had been sitting in an Indiana detention center for the past two months because of a clerical error. Immigration officials have been holding Amner Nunez-Vasquez without bond while trying to fast-track his deportation to Honduras. He is one of two people in the state being held by federal agents in Indianapolis this year. His attorney alleges wrongful detention as his case is reviewed, noting he has no prior criminal record and challenges the criteria for expedited removal.

stories.headline: Pence gets JFK award for Jan. 6 courage
stories.summary: Former Vice President Mike Pence received the John F. Kennedy Profile in Courage Award for certifying the results of the 2020 presidential election and ensuring peaceful transfer of power after the Jan. 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol attack. In accepting the award, Pence reflected on the difficulty and significance of his actions despite political pressures. The award is traditionally given to public servants who demonstrate courageous decision-making despite personal and professional consequences.

stories.headline: Shooting near courthouse
stories.summary: A man fatally shot by Hendricks County deputies in Danville is identified as Mark Vawter, 65, who is the great-grandfather of two young children. The incident occurred as deputies were transporting inmates to the courthouse and Vawter pulled out a gun and pointed it toward the group. Deputies returned fire, killing Vawter. The incident is under investigation and charges are pending for another driver involved in a prior related accident.

stories.headline: Pick for top prosecutor in D.C. loses key GOP support
stories.summary: Republican senators opposed the White House pick for the top federal prosecutor in D.C. ahead of a critical deadline, signaling a brewing showdown over President Donald Trump’s controversial nomination. Opposition from Sen. Thom Tillis and others revealed that the pick was facing significant hurdles in securing bipartisan support.

stories.headline: A beloved teacher fearing deportation bids farewell
stories.summary: Jesús Rodríguez, a Venezuelan national and music teacher, faced the risk of deportation as his humanitarian parole was set to expire. Choosing to avoid incarceration upon potential detainment, Rodríguez and his family decided to leave the United States for Spain. The story highlights the challenges faced by immigrants living under uncertain legal statuses.

stories.headline: Trump’s focus flips from prosperity to austerity
stories.summary: During his campaign and early part of his current presidency, Donald Trump promised economic prosperity and growth. However, by the time he reached his final campaign rally in Grand Rapids, Michigan, his tone shifted towards austerity and caution, warning about sacrifice and transition rather than economic expansion.

stories.headline: U.S. urged Ukraine to accept deportees
stories.summary: The Trump administration earlier this year urged Ukraine to accept unspecific numbers of U.S. deportees who are citizens of other countries, according to documents reviewed by The Washington Post. The documents suggest the U.S. pressured Ukraine despite concerns about deporting people to a war-torn nation with ongoing conflict.

stories.headline: Prison proposal gets rocky response
stories.summary: In San Francisco, tourists and locals scoff at the president's plan to reopen Alcatraz Island as a prison. The idea, rooted in legend and characterized by harsh rhetoric, is seen as a symbolic but controversial move. Visitors viewed the proposal with skepticism, recalling Alcatraz's history as a legendary but closed federal prison.

stories.headline: India hits Pakistan in retaliatory strikes
stories.summary: The Indian military launched strikes against Pakistan in retaliation for a militant attack in Kashmir that occurred last month. The strikes targeted nine sites related to terrorist attacks and were swift and condemned by Pakistan. The situation raises fears of escalating conflict between the two countries.

stories.headline: Germany Elevates Leader After Vote Fails Once
stories.summary: Germany's Parliament voted to make Friedrich Merz the country's chancellor after a second vote was needed due to failure of the first one. The new chancellor faces challenges including rebuilding Germany's leadership and managing political tensions within the ruling coalition.

stories.headline: Air-Traffic Control In Chaos: ‘We Don’t Have a Radar’
stories.summary: Following multiple tech failures and near misses in air-traffic control, the Trump administration has pledged an overhaul. Incidents included loss of radar tracking and poor communication at Newark Liberty International Airport leading to dangerous situations and warnings to pilots.

stories.headline: Tariffs Herald Wedding Season Of Costco Flowers, American Wine
stories.summary: Couples planning weddings are adjusting to rising costs due to tariffs, opting for less extravagant choices such as smaller flower arrangements and less expensive wine selections from traditional European vendors amid price increases on imports.

stories.headline: Washington's Trade War Spurs Other Nations to Make Deals
stories.summary: As the U.S. steps back from free trade under President Trump, countries like South America, Mexico, Canada, and Asia are forming new trade agreements, seeking to reduce dependence on U.S. tariffs and policies, which are seen as protectionist and disruptive to global trade flows.

stories.headline: India Strikes Pakistan Over Kashmir Attack
stories.summary: India launched retaliatory strikes against Pakistan following an attack on tourists in Kashmir, escalating tensions between the two nuclear-armed neighbors. The move signals a significant escalation in the ongoing conflict in the Kashmir region.

stories.headline: U.S. Steps Up Greenland Spying
stories.summary: The U.S. is increasing its intelligence-gathering efforts regarding Greenland, focusing on surveillance satellites and communications intercepts to counter perceived threats. This escalation comes amid concerns about Greenland's independence and security significance in the Arctic region.

stories.headline: Michelada Fest canceled over fears around ‘political climate,’ artist boycott
stories.summary: The Michelada Fest has been canceled due to concerns over the current political climate and threats of boycott from artists, reflecting tensions in the local cultural scene.

stories.headline: Chicago-area philanthropist & mountaineer battling cancer dies during climb in Nepal
stories.summary: A well-known Chicago-area philanthropist and mountaineer who was battling cancer has died during a climb in Nepal, highlighting the risks he took despite his illness.

stories.headline: As Conclave Commences, A Look at the Challenges Awaiting the New Pope
stories.summary: With the papal conclave beginning, this story explores the various challenges awaiting the new pope as he steps into his role at the Vatican.

stories.headline: Trump Tower Opens Borders
stories.summary: After blocking the public from the riverfront plaza outside the president's namesake building for months in defiance of regulations, the building management has finally removed 'no trespassing' barricades under pressure from the city.

stories.headline: Pritzker to testify in D.C. next month about Illinois’ sanctuary policy
stories.summary: Illinois Governor Pritzker is scheduled to testify in Washington D.C. next month regarding the state's sanctuary policy, a significant development in the ongoing political debate.
